snippet: United States-imposed laws are central to the protest movement, as those who once helped the American military now sometimes put innocent people in prison in their work as informants for the Iraqi government.
abstract: Sunni protest movement in Iraq is turning increasingly violent, freshening memories of sectarian conflict of 2006 and raising troubling parallels to Syrian civil war; at core of protests is set of laws and practices imposed by United States in earliest days of occupation, effects of which linger under Iraq's government.

byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi contributed reporting from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Baquba, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: United States-imposed laws are central to the protest movement, as those who once helped the American military now sometimes put innocent people in prison in their work as informants for the Iraqi government.

headline.seo: Sunnis in Iraq Protest Antiterror Tactics That Hurt Innocents
headline.main: Iraq’s Worsening Sunni Protests Revolve Around Antiterrorism Tactics
headline.print_headline: Iraq’s Worsening Sunni Protests Revolve Around Antiterrorism Tactics

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
